```{r, echo = FALSE}
songs <- read.csv2(here::here("data", "songs.csv"),header=TRUE, sep=",")
```

The tidyverse provides the `count()` function, a clean and expressive way to produce frequency tables. It takes a data frame and a variable, and returns a tibble with the variableâ€™s values and their frequencies.

```{r}
library(dplyr)
songs %>% count(THEME)
```

This gives a simple table with two columns:

- the category (e.g., levels of education)
- the number of cases in each category

If you want the categories sorted from most to least frequent, you can add:

```{r}
songs %>% count(THEME, sort = TRUE)
```

This replaces `sort(table(x))` with a single tidy and readable expression.
